titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Attended the Supreme Court, where the action commenced to be tried on Saturday, was this morning finished— In the afternoon An argument on a point of law was held— After the Court adjourned I walked.— Met my old Classmates Vose and J. Chandler; both of whom are representatives in the General Court. Spent the evening at Mr: J. Codman’s, with a Company of Ladies and Gentlemen— Play’d one game at whist.

2. Attended the Supreme Court, before whom two law questions were this day argued— Parsons says that whenever he argues a Cause, if besides the points he makes in the cause, the Court choose to make any of their own, operating in his favour, he always cautiously avoids saying a word upon that point— He leaves the full development of it to the Judges themselves, who are always so fond of deciding a cause upon a point of their own starting, that one such is better for the success of a Cause than twenty of the Counsel’s urging— But it must be entirely left to themselves, and the success is infallible.— I told him he look’d for that law to the black letter of the human heart— But Master Parsons is perhaps not quite sure of his own motive for leaving all points started by the Court, entirely to themselves— He will not enlarge upon their points, because he cannot persuade himself, and would not have them believe it possible, that any point material to a cause should occur to them and yet escape his sagacity— Naturam expellas furca, tamen usque recurret.— Judge Payne got a fall, and hurt his knee, which has deprived the Court of his attendance these two days— The Court have harmonized the better for it— On Saturday Lowell was arguing to the Jury, that on board ship the laws about assault and battery were not so rigorous as on shore— Judge Strong stopp’d him; saying “Mr: Lowell, we have not two laws, one for the land and another for the sea”— Payne, who always sets his face against subordinates complaining against their superiors, hardly suffered Strong to finish his sentence, before he broke out— “Yes, but we have, though— There’s the laws made at Oberon— You will find them in Molloy”— And spoke as he usually does when he contradicts Counsel at the Bar.
Mrs: Adams very unwell all this day; and at night, quite ill—

3. The principal trial at Court this day, was of a man, upon an information for erecting a wooden livery stable within the town of Boston— Found guilty, against the opinion of the Court— This finished the business of a criminal nature for this term— Club in the evening at Dr: Dexter’s— Somewhat thin.

4. A Cause of Jones agt: Hichborne and Swan came on at Court this day, in which Hichborne is but a nominal defendt: His sympathies were all with the other party; and in the course of it such personalities took place between him, and the Attorney General, that the Court were obliged to interfere— Hichborne insulted them nearly as much as he did Sullivan. The Chief Justice said he would not bear it; but that was all.— I received this morning a Commission of Bankruptcy, together with Mr: Goodale and Mr: Callender—and attended at Goodale’s Office at 5 in the afternoon— We were sworn by Justice Cooper, and subscribed the oath required by the Statute— We agreed to meet, for the examination at 10 to-morrow morning— Signed an appointment of a Secretary, (Heard,) and a notification to the person against whom the Commission issued to attend— After the business was over, Callender took me aside, and told me that as a second Secretary would probably be wanted, he wished to devote himself entirely to this business, and to be a candidate for it, in cases when he should not be Commissioner— I told him that though disposed to accommodate him as much as possible, I had promised to vote for Gay, in case a second Secretary should be necessary— There was a sale of books at Clap’s, which I attended, and where I made some purchases— In the evening, Mrs: Adams went with Mrs: Smith to the assembly; between 9 and 10 I went likewise, and stay’d a couple of hours— I knew a proportion of the company, nearly or quite as small, as at the ball I attended about three weeks since.

5. Attended at 10 this morning at Mr: Goodale’s office, and with the other Commissioners proceeded to declare Joseph Ripley a bankrupt— The Messenger, returned the notification to Ripley, back to the Commissioners with an endorsement, that he had served it by delivering a copy of it to Ripley himself at his place of abode— The petitioning creditor them proved his debt, by Oath, and in writing, with a description of the endorsed notes amounting to 1264:67 cents, from which the debt resulted— That Ripley was a trader, was sworn to and
and subscribed by Stephen Francis junr. who has lived with him as clerk— The act of bankruptcy, was in like manner proved by the deposition of Bell the deputy Sheriff, that he could not serve a writ upon him. After which we all signed the Declaration of Bankruptcy.— Then a notification to Ripley to appear before the Commissioners and surrender on the 8th: and 24th: of this month, and the 17th: of April at 11. A.M.— And lastly a Warrant to S. Bradford, to take possession of his effects.— This is the usual course of proceedings— Callender administered the Oaths.— Thence I went to my Office where I found Mr: Boylston.— Attended Court the remainder of the day, untill Evening— Then a meeting of the Society; where Mr: Popkin continued our electrical experiments. I was obliged to leave them at 9 o’clock, to go and pass the rest of the evening at Mr: J. Welles’s—where was a company of about 25. ladies and gentlemen— It was almost midnight, when we came home.

6. Attended the Court this forenoon, and heard a trial of the case Down vs Mackay— W. Shaw went out to Quincy. Dined at Mr: Smith’s— Mr: H. Storer, Mr: Parsons and Miss Bishop there.— Mild weather and rain— Mrs: A. came home at about 8 in the evening. But I have so severe a cold and hoarseness that I could not read to her— Parsons said this morning, that whenever the chief Justice got an idea into his head, in the course of a cause, which operated against any client of his, he made it always his sole object to get a continuance; for it was utterly in vain to contend against it, during the term— But if that could be got over, and Mr: Dana have time to go investigate the subject untill another term, his mind then was as open to cool argument, as that of any man— I told him he ought to give him a hint of this imm directly to himself— He said he had done it repeatedly.

7— Attended at Mr: Emerson’s in the forenoon, and at Mr: Kirkland’s after dinner— Kirkland preached himself. Weather cold; and grew colder towards night— My hoarseness prevented me from reading to Mrs: Adams— Wrote therefore, some minutes from the bankrupt act, and the Supreme Court minutes— Read the first sermon, in the fourth volume of Tillotson— Upon sincerity.

8. A Fire this morning, near Charlestown bridge— Burnt one wooden house— I call’d at Mrs: Whitwell’s, and received from her a quarter’s rent— Attended the meeting of the Commissioners of Bankruptcy, in the case of Joseph Ripley— Several creditors proved their debts— They disagreed with respect to the appointment of a provisional assignee which was accordingly not done— Benjn: Dana, a broker, proved a debt and produced two notes of hand, which were received— He afterwards return’d to the Office, with Rufus Amory, and wished to withdraw his claim, alledging that he had monies belonging to Ripley—a balance, upon other notes which he sold for him— But we referred him to the assignee— After the meeting was over I attended Court the remainder of the day— Evening at home— Attempted to read in Locke to Mrs: A— but found myself too hoarse— I took a turn in the mall before breakfast, and one before going home in the evening.

9. Walk’d in the Mall before breakfast. Attended the Court all day— Two jury trials; neither of which turn’d upon any question of law— H. Townsend dined with me— Court sat untill after seven in the evening. Spent an hour or two at Mr: Smith’s, with Company, Ladies and Gentlemen.

10. Met at Mr: Goodale’s office, and with Messrs: Tudor and Callender took the oath as Commissioners in the case of Samuel Albree— Attended the Supreme Court the rest of the day, and spent the evening with a numerous company at Mr: Gardner Greene’s— Whist with Mrs: Knox, Mrs: Babcock, and Jos: Hall— Home between 9. and 10 o’clock— Just as we were going to bed we were alarmed by a cry of fire— It continued for three or four hours, and burnt a number of Stores on Spear’s wharf and the long wharf.

11. Attended the supreme Court, all day. In the evening went to the ball— El: Smith and Miss Bishop; with Mr: Parsons went with us.— The ball being the last for the Season was very full— I Danced, and play’d whist— Home not much earlier than 12. at night.

12. At the office of the Commissioners of bankruptcy at 11. o’clock this morning— Samuel Albree declared a bankrupt. At the Supreme Court afterwards— This afternoon they dismiss’d the juries— In the evening we had a meeting of
our society, and Quincy lectured upon electricity— We broke two of our Leyden jars by charging them too highly— I took several shocks, and a succession of sparks, standing on the insulating stool, applied to my shoulder, which for several days past has suffered considerably with the rhumatism— I am to be the lecturer myself next week— Paid Dr: Parker $3531:50 towards discharging my bond and mortgage to him.

13. I find myself much benefited by the application of electricity last evening to my rheumatism— Attended the Supreme Court, which this day finally adjourned, after a session of five weeks, without getting half through their list of continued entries— Spent the afternoon at my office— Evening at home— Read Locke’s chapter upon infinity, but my hoarseness compell’d me to desist— George broke out yesterday with the meazles.

14. Several alarms of fire in the course of this day; the weather being cold and windy— But happily no damage was done— Went with Mrs: Adams to Quincy, and dined with my parents— Return’d in the evening— The roads are tolerable— Read two or three chapters of Locke’s essay.

15. Walk in the mall before breakfast.— Day at my office— Resumed the reading of Park on insurance, which has been interrupted by the Session of the Supreme Court— In the afternoon I called at Dr: Jackson’s to make some experiments but he was not there— Walk again before evening, in the mall— Qualified as Commissioner in the case of Roylance Child—with Messrs: Tudor and Callender— Read in the evening a few pages in Locke (the chapter of power) but from hoarseness was obliged to desist— Mr: Shaw called on me this afternoon, and I went for him to the probate-Office— 10th: of May appointed for Mr: Shaw the Admr: to account— The clerk in the probate-office mentioned to me that a young Man by the name of Rockwood, now at Harvard College, and to graduate next summer, wishes to be received as a student in my office.

16. Attended upon the commission of bankruptcy against Roylance Child, at ten this morning. Child is in prison, and Thurston as the petitioning creditor’s attorney, wished to make a Sheriff’s return that he could not serve a writ upon him, answer for proof of an act of bankruptcy— This being rejected, he produced an assignment from Child to his brother of all his property for the payment of certain debts to the exclusion of others— And Thurston then gravely read an authority to shew that such a fraudulent assignment is an act of bankruptcy— Upon enquiry how the paper came into his hands, it appeared that he had received it from the brother, in whose favour it was made; received it, for the express purpose of using in this manner— As therefore this was manifestly a concerted transaction between the two brothers it was likewise rejected— Finally proof was given that Child has been in prison for debt from the 7th: of last July to this day, and this was a sufficient act of bankruptcy— The declaration of the commissioners was therefore founded upon it— I called at Dr: Jackson’s in the afternoon to make some experiments, but he succeeded tolerably well, as far as we went.— Evening at home; and read some pages in Locke.

17. Mr: Boylston was at my office in the forenoon— Quincy called after dinner— Reading Park, and Sullivan’s history of land-titles, in Massachusetts— Received this afternoon letters from Mrs: Susanna Hall and Mr: E. J. Lee, at Alexandria, with papers respecting a demand of Mrs: Hall’s— Spent the evening and supp’d at Mr: J. T. Apthorp’s about 30 ladies and gentlemen of the company— Play’d whist with the eldest Miss Payne, Miss Gray & Jonn: Amory. W. Sullivan sung after supper.

18. Mr: F. Hall brought me a rect: for the 68th: & 69th: assessments on my shares of the Middlesex Canal, for which I gave him a check on the Bank— Attended to Mrs: Hall’s affair but could not see Mr: W. Gray, of whom I am to make enquiries— J. Gardner was at my office in the forenoon, and dined with us— Spent the afternoon at Dr: Jackson’s continuing to make experiments; but the weather was so warm and sultry, that we found it almost impossible to excite the cylinder, and wholly so to charge a jar— Hence scarcely any of the experiments succeeded. Evening at Mr: Storer’s— Mr: Smith and Mr: Quincy were there.

19. H. Townsend call’d to see me, this forenoon— Qualified, as Commissioner in the case of John Soley.— My mother came to town, and dined with us— Returned to Quincy this afternoon— I went to Dr: Jackson’s, and prepared for the evening— During which I was the lecturer, on the subject of the electrical spark, and the influence of points— I had not found time to finish my synopsis— Louisa Smith came to spend some days with Mrs: Adams— Letters to W. Gray & E. J. Lee.

20. Private meeting of Commissioners, and declared John Soley a Bankrupt— Employed most of the forenoon. Callender mentioned that Ripley’s creditors have it in contemplation to chuse himself as a joint assignee of his own estate, to which I am not prepared to assent, as it appears incompatible with the policy of the law.— Dined at Mr: Jonn: Jackson’s. Mr: Parsons, Mr: W. Smith, Charles & George Storer, Dr: Jackson, and Gardner & his wife were there. Evening at home—reading poetry to the ladies.— Weather which has been the last two days at summer heat is cold again, with rain and snow.

21. Heard Mr: Emerson, both parts of the day— Saw Mr: Freeman before dinner, and asked him to come on Wednesday, to marry Whitcomb and Epps; which he promised.— Louisa Smith pass’d the evening at Mrs: Smith’s— Read a sermon of Tillotson— On the excellency of Abraham’s faith— And in the evening part of Locke’s Essay.

22. Had a letter this morning from Mr: W. Gray of Salem— Forenoon at my office—reading in Park— In the afternoon attended at the Commissioner’s Office— 1st: Meeting of Samuel Albree— He surrendered— Mr: Gay, as Assignee of William Remington, another bankrupt, appeared as a claimant upon his effects— Produced a couple of promissory notes; one a very small one to Remington himself; the other for 700 dollars, with two indorsements— Albree said he had in the beginning of December paid up most of the large note, by other notes— Mr: Tudor asked him why he had not taken up the large note— He said because Remington called upon him in the morning before breakfast, in a great hurry and a great passion— But he had promised him at the time to give him up the note.— There were two other bankrupts there (Simonds’s) who said they had given notes and indorsements, without booking them— “I don’t wonder you all become bankrupts[”]—said Tudor—[“]if you do business in this way”— He said there were at least two millions of this floating nothing, in this town, which they call’d money. T’would soon be as bad as in paper money times— It became a question how Gay, should prove his debt— He found the form in Cook— The Assignee and bankrupt must both swear to it— Tudor mentioned that Saml: Prince another bankrupt, who had made over to his brother James Prince property to a large amount; since his act of bankruptcy had directed the post-master to deliver all letters from him, to his brother James— James in consequence of this has got possession of a large venture arrived in a vessel here for Sam since the commission issued— Louisa Smith spent the evening at Miss Payne’s— Took my walks morn and eve in the Mall— Read in Locke’s Essay—on Substance—complex ideas of it—and relations.

23. Day at my Office—reading Park—and Mr: Sullivan’s History of Land-titles— Evening, Supper and Ball at Mr: Quincy’s—with a company of about 60 ladies and Gentlemen— Stay’d till almost 2 in the morning.

24. Second meeting of Ripley’s Commissioners— The creditors chose two assignees— William Mackay & C. Bradbury. They gave up the point of chusing Ripley himself as one— Mr: Freeman called at my house after dinner, and declined marrying Whitcomb and Epps, owing to an irregularity in the certificate— Mr: Gardner therefore married them— At 7 I called on Mr: Smith, and went with him to the club at Mr: Kirkland’s. Home at 10. in the eve Mrs: A. unwell.

25. Executed the assignment of Jos: Ripley’s Estate and effects to W. Mackay and C. Bradbury— Mr: Boylston called at my Office. At noon, met with the Committee of the Academy, for publications; at the State house— Sat till 2. We agreed not to interfere with any papers considered by the former Committee— Dined at Mr: John Amory junrs: with a company of gentlemen— Was call’d home to Mrs Adams, who had been taken very ill, after walking this afternoon— Dr: Welsh attended her. She recovered a little in the course of the Evening.

26. Mrs: A— had a poor night, but is this day somewhat better— Judge Davis called at my Office this morning at 10. Had some conversation with him relative to Mr: Boylston’s affairs— Mr: Boylston called likewise— Read a little in Park, and afternoon in Mr: Sullivan’s Land titles— Evening at the Society— Mr: Williams read an analysis of Dr: Van Marum’s experiments, with his large electrical apparatus at Haerlem— We broke up early— I called this morning on Mr: Rogers to treat with him for the purchase of a pew.

27. First meeting of the Commissioners of Roylance Child— No creditors appeared— Callender went and took his surrender at the gaol— Louisa Smith went to Dr: Welsh’s— My father’s carriage came into town for us and we went out to Quincy after dinner. Weather very cold.

28. The winter seems returning with its utmost severity— Rose very late— Heard Mr: Whitney in the forenoon. Mr: Thayer dined with us. George very unwell this afternoon— Mrs: Cranch at tea— B. Adams and his wife Miss Beale, Mr: Wales &c in the evening. Wrote my brother.

29. Deacon French and Doctor Tufts called this morning— Wrote the notes and a deed for my father, for the purchase of Mr: Quincy’s estate. We return’d to Boston before dinner— Afternoon at my office— Resumed the 1st volume of Blackstone’s Commentaries— Walk’d in the Mall— Excessively chilly— Evening at home and read to Mrs: A— the chapter in Locke’s Essay on identity and diversity— Took George into our bed-chamber.

30. Snow in the night, and more moderate weather this day— Mr: Boylston called at my Office— Continued reading Park, and in the evening, read Locke’s defence of his opinions concerning identity, against Stillingfleet’s objections.

31. Qualified this forenoon, as Commissioner of W. Micklefield— In the afternoon had a 2d: meeting in the case of Samuel Albree— But the petitioning creditor was absent, and no creditor appeared, with a demand adequate to the choice of an Assignee— Adjourn’d the meeting to the 12th: of next month.— Evening at Club— Mr: Popkin’s.

Day— Rise, from 6 to 7. Read on electricity, or write on the bankrupt Law till 9— In fair weather walk an hour in the Mall— And sometimes bring up my journal and accounts— Breakfast between 9 and 10.— Market, half an hour. At my Office, or the bankrupt office untill 2— Read & analyze Park at my Office— Home to dinner— Return to my Office between 3 and 4. There or at the bankrupt office untill dark— Evening once a week at club, once at the Society— Occasionally out in company, and three or four times a week at home reading Locke to Mrs: Adams.
